overview.text:
Assistance needs due to armed conflict and frequent natural disasters include food, healthcare, and protection. 9.3 million people are reported in need of humanitarian assistance. 67,721 people were affected, by natural disasters (floods, earthquakes, droughts, landslides and mudflows), between 31 January and 30 July. The security environment is highly volatile and has deteriorated since the withdrawal of most international forces at the end of 2014. Between January 2009 and 30 June 2016, a total of 63,934 casualties were recorded, including 22,941 deaths and 40,993 injures. The Taliban increased their influence throughout 2015 – including attacks on provincial capitals towards the end of the year – and have continued this trend in the first months of 2016. Islamic State (IS) presence has been growing in the east, with significant activity reported in Nangarhar. Increased insecurity and economic challenges caused a significant increase in the outflow of people from Afghanistan throughout 2015, despite calls from the government to stay and contribute to reconstruction of the country. The outflow continued in the first months of 2016.

Abuses against Afghans in Pakistan appear to have worsened substantially since June. This has resulted in a mass influx of Afghans from Pakistan back into Afghanistan, putting a strain on the resources and coping capacity of the Afghan government and humanitarian organisations.

appeals.name: Afghanistan 2016
Afghanistan Flash Appeal: One million people on the move (September - December 2016)

overview.text:
Some 2.7 million people, almost 10% of the population, are in need of humanitarian assistance, primarily in Far North, North, Adamaoua, and East regions. Conflict in both Nigeria and CAR has led to displacement of refugees to Cameroon. The spread of Boko Haram activities from Nigeria into Cameroon’s Far North region has caused insecurity and internal displacement, and in the east, there are reports of armed groups from CAR in border areas. ?  In 2016, Boko Haram attacks against civilians have killed up to 216 people. ? Up to 480 civilians were killed in Boko Haram attacks in Cameroon between June 2015 and June 2016. Needs remain high in Minawao camp, where more than 58,100 refugees are registered. ?
INFORM considers Cameroon's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster is of concern, at 4.6/10, as well as Cameroon's vulnerability, at 5.5/10.

figures.name: People Assisted with WFP Food Aid

overview.text:
Failure of the state has resulted in displacement, targeted killings along communal lines, and human rights abuses. Protection, humanitarian access, and food security are priority needs, as continued violence, looting, and displacement cause further deterioration of an already dire humanitarian situation across the country. Needs continue to exceed available resources and delivery of aid is expected to decline because funding remains low.
INFORM measures CAR's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be extremely high, at 8.3/10. CAR's vulnerability is of particular concern.

Central African Republic Regional Refugee Response Plan 2016 (Cameroon, Chad, Republic of Congo, Democratic Republic of the Congo)

figures.name: People Assisted with WFP Food Aid

overview.text:
Over 2.3 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance in Chad, including more than one million severely food insecure in the Sahelian belt, and more than 100,000 displaced in Lac, eastern and southern regions. The country faces security threats on its periphery, most notably from Boko Haram in Lac region, as attacks have targeted civilians and military operations have driven people from their homes. Nigerian refugees have been crossing into Chad since 2014, adding to large refugee populations from Sudan in the east, and Central African Republic in the south, with refugees from both countries still seeking refuge in Chad.
Underlying vulnerability and food insecurity is high, particularly in the Sahelian zone to the north of the country, where desertification and inconsistent rains impact on agro-pastoral livelihoods.
INFORM measures Chad's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster at 6/10. Vulnerability as well as lack of coping capacity are of particular concern, at alarming rates of 7.4/10 and 9/10.

figures.name: Children under 5 with Severe Acute Malnutrition

overview.text:
A complex emergency has persisted in DRC for more than 20 years. Conflict between foreign, self-defence, and other armed groups, mainly impacting the eastern provinces, has left the country in a state of prolonged, severe humanitarian crisis. Although the security situation has improved slightly since 2013, when the government defeated M23 in Nord-Kivu, humanitarian needs remain and conflict continues to cause displacement. Clashes between armed groups and the DRC armed forces are affecting populations mainly in Sud- and Nord-Kivu, Ituri, Tanganyika, and Haut-Katanga provinces. Health is a priority due to recurrent measles, cholera, and malaria outbreaks, and protection concerns are high because of serious human rights violations perpetrated by armed groups and the military in the eastern provinces. Access remains volatile in the east, and lack of infrastructure is a general problem across the country.
The ruling coalition is attempting to prolong President Joseph Kabila’s time in office beyond November 2016, when his constitutional two-term limit is due to end. Since the beginning of the year, election-related violence has increased. Protests related to the forthcoming presidential elections have taken place in Kinshasa, Lubumbashi, Bukavu, and Goma. Election-related human rights violations, and restrictions on freedom of expression, and freedom of assembly, have been reported since 2015.
INFORM measures DRC's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 6.9/10. DRC's lack of coping capacity is of particular concern.

overview.text:
Consecutive, below-average rainy seasons have caused severe drought across northern, eastern, and central Ethiopia. This is leading to high levels of food insecurity, particularly in Afar, in Sitti zone of Somali region, and parts of Amhara, Oromia, and SNNPR. Malnutrition has increased significantly. 
Hosting over 737,000 refugees from neighbouring countries, including 286,000 from South Sudan, the majority of Ethiopia’s refugee camps have reached full capacity, and overcrowding, malnutrition, and critical shortfalls in humanitarian aid are of concern. Most refugees have been in protracted displacement, but remain in need of assistance.
INFORM measures Ethiopia's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 6.4/10. Ethiopia's vulnerability is of particular concern, at 6.6/10.

Children Suffering from Severe Acute Malnutrition

overview.text: Humanitarian needs in Haiti stem from displacement, food insecurity, and malnutrition. The situation is compounded by an extremely fragile political and economic situation, and a significant vulnerability to natural disasters, including hurricanes, floods, earthquakes, landslides, and droughts. A cholera outbreak has persisted since October 2010. The resilience of the population is extremely low. Since the beginning of 2015, 80% of Haiti has been affected by El Niño conditions, and around one million Haitians have been affected by drought. Flooding damaged houses in April and May, and the hurricane season, which commenced in June 2016, is expected to be more severe than normal.

appeals.name: Haiti 2016

figures.name: Children under 5 with Severe Acute Malnutrition

overview.text: The Islamic State insurgency has compounded an already fragile political and humanitarian situation, and led to international military intervention. Iraq now hosts 3.3 million IDPs, one of the largest internally displaced populations in the world.? IDPs and Syrian refugees make up 25% of the population in the Kurdistan Region of Iraq (KR-I).? Access constraints and human rights violations from all warring parties are of major concern. After military stalemate characterised much of 2015, government operations to retake territory from Islamic State have stepped up in 2016, triggering further displacement and humanitarian needs, particularly in Anbar and Mosul corridors. According to FAO projections, between 12 and 13 million people in Iraq will likely be in need humanitarian aid by the end of 2016.

appeals.name: Iraq 2016
Mosul Flash Appeal 2016

overview.text:
Insecurity persists in northern and central regions. Tensions persist among armed groups, as well as between ethnic groups. Furthermore, terrorist attacks sporadically occur. A lack of access to basic social services and the weak capacity of public administration drive humanitarian needs. While IDPs and refugees have slowly been returning home since 2013, over 39,000 people remain internally displaced and around 134,000 refugees are still in neighbouring countries.
INFORM measures Mali's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 6.6/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity and vulnerability are all at alarming levels, at 6.2/10, 6.8/10 and 6.7/10.

appeals.name: Mali 2016

figures.name: People Assisted with WFP Food Aid
Malian Refugees in Burkina Faso, Mauritania and Niger

overview.text:
Protracted armed conflict between ethnic groups and the government continues to keep over 500,000 people in need of assistance. The end of 2015 saw landmark elections and a national ceasefire agreement, but several groups remain in armed conflict with the government, predominantly in Kachin, Shan, and Rakhine states. In Rakhine state, discrimination against the Rohingya Muslim minority has caused protracted displacement. IDPs in Rakhine have limited access to services, as their movement is restricted to the camps.

Damage to agriculture from flooding and landslides in 2015 will continue to impact on livelihoods and food security in 2016. The rainy season normally occurs over May-November; as of August 2016 over 493,000 people are displaced or evacuated because of floods  in Mandalay, Magway, Sagaing, Ayeyarwady, Rakhine, Mon, Yangon, Bago, Kachin and Chin. More rainfall and flooding are expected, as flood water is moving south. 

INFORM measures Myanmar's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster at 6.8/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity and vulnerability are all at alarming levels, with rates of 7.7/10 and 7/10 and 5.8/10.

appeals.name: Myanmar 2016

figures.name: IDPs in Kachin and Northern Shan
People Assisted with WFP Food Aid

overview.text: Violence in the northeast has caused massive displacement and at the same time restricted movement: it has disrupted food supplies, seriously hindered access to basic services, and limited agricultural activities. In seven years of conflict, over 20,000 people have been killed in Boko Haram-related incidents. People affected by violence in Adamawa, Borno, and Yobe, and neighbouring Bauchi, Taraba, and Gombe states are in urgent need of protection, shelter, food, and access to health services and education. Since February 2016, as humanitarian access is increasing, extreme food insecurity and malnutrition conditions have been revealed in Borno state.

appeals.name: Nigeria 2016
Nigeria Regional Refugee Response Plan 2016 (Cameroon, Chad, Niger)

overview.text:
Ensuring the delivery of essential services including healthcare, food, water and electricity remain of concern across the Gaza strip and the West Bank due to access restrictions imposed by Israel and neighbouring countries. Needs are particularly acute in Gaza, where around 75,000 Palestinians remain displaced from the 50-day war in 2014 and the ongoing blockade continues to severely restrict the delivery of services and the movement of people and goods.
INFORM measures Colombia's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be high, at 6.1/10. Hazard and exposure as well as vulnerability are a particular concern, both at 6.8/10 rates.

overview.text: Al Shabaab’s insurgency coupled with severe El Niño-induced drought has created large-scale displacement and made basic services virtually inaccessible for an estimated 4.9 million Somalis; these give rise to an INFORM index score of 9.0 out of 10, the highest  score of any country. Humanitarian access remains extremely limited outside of Somaliland, particularly in Lower and Upper Juba regions, which are completely inaccessible. The government’s control is essentially limited to Mogadishu and surrounding areas, however Al Shabaab attacks in the city persist. Landmark parliamentary elections are currently scheduled for 30 October 2016, the first since 1967, which provide a significant step for improved political stability.

overview.text:
Violence spread across eastern and northern South Sudan in December 2013 after President Kiir accused Vice President Riek Machar of plotting a coup against him. The conflict has become increasingly intercommunal in nature, with the Dinka allied to President Kiir, and the Nuer loosely allied with Vice President Riek Machar. A ceasefire agreement was signed in August 2015, and a transitional government was created in April 2016. Clashes between government forces and opposition groups, however, have continued. A growing number of active armed groups are appearing that are not party to the peace agreement. 

The conflict has mostly been concentrated in Jonglei, Upper Nile, and Unity states, spreading to Western Equatoria in November 2015. Since February, however, these areas have been relatively calm, while fighting has significantly escalated in Western Bahr el Ghazal. In early July in Juba, forces loyal to President Salva Kiir clashed with those loyal to Reik Machar, echoing events that triggered the conflict in 2013 and raising concerns of a return to full-scale civil war.
Food insecurity and malnutrition rates are unprecedented, and insecurity is hampering the delivery of assistance. The UN reports widespread violation of human rights and targeted violence against civilians.
INFORM measures South Sudan's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be extremely high, at 8.3/10. South Sudan's vulnerability is measured at 9.3/10.

appeals.name: Republic of South Sudan 2016
South Sudan Regional Refugee Response Plan 2016 (CAR, DRC, Ethiopia, Kenya, Sudan and Uganda)

People Assisted by WFP in 2016 (per month)

overview.text:
Protracted insurgencies are being waged by armed groups across Darfur, South Kordofan, and Blue Nile. Darfur has been the scene of conflict for over a decade, while violence in Blue Nile and South Kordofan increased significantly after South Sudan gained independence in 2011. Humanitarian access to conflict zones is severely restricted.
Violence, food insecurity, malnutrition, lack of access to basic services, and recurrent drought and flooding have caused large-scale internal displacement.
INFORM measures Sudan's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 7.1/10. Sudan's lack of coping capacity, high vulnerability and high hazard exposure are of particular concern.

Sudan 2016
Yemen Regional Refugee and Migrant Response Plan 2016 (Djibouti, Ethiopia, Somalia, Sudan, Regional)

overview.text:
13.5 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance inside Syria, including 6.1 million IDPs.

Conflict has killed over 300,000 people, including 86,000 civilians, and caused large-scale displacement. Protection concerns are widespread. WASH and access to food are high priorities, as well as access to health services. Humanitarian needs in areas under prolonged and ongoing siege are particularly high because access is obstructed.
Aleppo has seen intense fighting since the end of the truce brokered in early September, which excluded Islamist groups such as IS and Jabhat Fateh al Sham. The Syrian army, with Russian support, has launched a major offensive in Aleppo, with airstrikes reported to have killed hundreds of people. All armed actors are present in Aleppo governorate and it is expected that the fighting will continue to escalate in the coming months. 
INFORM measures Syria's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster to be very high, at 6.6/10. Syria's highly violent conflict intensity is of particular concern.

overview.text:
A ceasefire has not halted fighting that first escalated in Yemen in March 2015, and more than 21 million people are in need of humanitarian aid. The Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC) declared Yemen a Level 3 emergency in July 2015.
An armed advance on the capital by Houthis from the north has led to civil war throughout the country. A coalition led by Saudi Arabia has supported the Yemeni government with airstrikes that began in March 2015. Activities by southern secessionists, Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP), and Islamic State (IS) compound the security and political challenges.
INFORM measures Yemen's risk of humanitarian crisis and disaster at 7.5/10. Hazard and exposure as well as lack of coping capacity and vulnerability are at alarming rates of 8.1/10, 7.9/10 and 6.5/10.
